choices.text: Hypertension in the supine position with postural hypotension

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits her doctor complaining of feeling tired all the time for the last few months. She has had amenorrhea for 6 months and has been feeling dizzy while getting up in the morning. Which of the following clinical signs would the family doctor be most likely to find if the diagnosis were thought to be Addison's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) is characterised by deficient cortisol and aldosterone production, with elevated ACTH.
  • Excess ACTH cross-reacts with melanocortin receptors, leading to generalised hyperpigmentation, especially in sun-exposed areas, buccal mucosa, palmar creases, and pressure points.
  • Other typical symptoms include weight loss, fatigue, dizziness due to postural hypotension, amenorrhoea, and salt craving.
  • The combination of chronic fatigue, amenorrhoea, and mucosal pigmentation makes Addison's disease the most likely diagnosis here.

Explanation of other options:

Diminished body hair (Option B): Seen in secondary adrenal insufficiency (low ACTH, low androgens), not primary Addison's.

Pallor (Option C): May be present in chronic illness but not specific; hyperpigmentation is the hallmark.

Hypertension with postural hypotension (Option D): Addison's usually causes hypotension, not hypertension.

questions.text: A 36-year-old HIV-positive man, evaluated for weight loss and weakness, has been found to have disseminated tuberculosis. On examination, he is hypotensive and has hyperpigmentation of the mucosa, elbows and skin creases. Further investigations confirm a diagnosis of Addison's disease. Which of the following is likely in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) results in low aldosterone, causing impaired renal excretion of potassium- leading to hyperkalemia.
  • Hyponatremia is also typical due to sodium loss and impaired renal sodium reabsorption.
  • Patients may also develop metabolic acidosis due to loss of bicarbonate reabsorption.
  • Hyperpigmentation is due to elevated ACTH and melanocyte-stimulating hormone.
  • Tuberculosis is a common cause of Addison's disease in developing countries.

Explanation of other options:

Increased serum Na (Option A): Addison's disease is associated with low sodium, not increased.

Increased serum Cl (Option B): Usually normal or low, not typically increased.

Increased serum HCO3 (Option C): Patients usually have metabolic acidosis, so bicarbonate is low, not high.

questions.text: Aldosterone synthesis is stimulated by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mineralocorticoid secretion is stimulated by hypotension, hyperkalemia, angiotensin II, ACTH, and hyponatremia, in decreasing order of potency.
  • Of these, hyperkalemia is the most important stimulus, as aldosterone secretion helps restore potassium balance by promoting renal excretion.

Explanation of other options:

ACTH (Option A) does stimulate aldosterone secretion but its effect is transient and weak, mainly important for baseline regulation. The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is far more significant in long-term control.

Hypernatremia (Option C): High sodium levels actually suppress aldosterone secretion because the body does not need additional sodium reabsorption. Therefore, hypernatremia is not a physiological stimulus.

Exogenous steroids (Option D): Glucocorticoids given externally can cause negative feedback suppression of ACTH and aldosterone. Hence, they reduce rather than stimulate aldosterone synthesis.

choices.text: Blood taken from a drip arm

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has been diagnosed with diarrhoea. His blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, and his temperature is 38°C. Blood results show Na 118 mmol/l, K 2.8 mmol/l, urea 8 mg/dl, creatinine 0.4 mg/dl, chloride 70 mmol/l, bicarbonate 20 mmol/l. Serum osmolality is 287 mosm/l, and urine osmolality is 700 mosm/l. Which is the most likely diagnosis for hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • There is hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and low urea but with a normal serum osmolality.
  • This unusual combination is most likely due to inaccurate sampling from a drip arm, where the sample gets diluted with IV fluid.
  • In Addisonian crisis or diarrhoeal salt loss, we would expect raised urea and potassium with hypovolemia. (Options A and B ruled out)
  • In SIADH, serum osmolality would be low and not within the normal range as seen here. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is the outermost layer of the adrenal gland?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The adrenal glands lie above the kidneys and are divided into the cortex and medulla.
  • The outermost layer of the adrenal cortex is the zona glomerulosa, which secretes aldosterone under the control of angiotensin II and potassium levels.
  • The zona fasciculata, lying beneath, primarily secretes cortisol under the influence of ACTH. (Option B ruled out)
  • The zona reticularis is the innermost cortical layer and produces androgens (DHEA), also under ACTH control. (Option C ruled out)
  • The adrenal medulla lies centrally and secretes catecholamines (adrenaline and noradrenaline) in response to sympathetic stimulation. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: The basic substrate for steroidogenesis in the adrenal gland is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cholesterol is the essential precursor for all adrenal steroid hormones, including glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and androgens.
  • It is derived from both dietary sources and endogenous synthesis in the liver and adrenal cortex.
  • Steroidogenesis begins with the transport of cholesterol into the mitochondria, where it is converted to pregnenolone by the enzyme cholesterol desmolase (CYP11A1).
  • Pregnenolone then serves as the common precursor for the biosynthesis of cortisol, aldosterone, and adrenal androgens.
  • Triglycerides provide energy but are not substrates for steroid hormone synthesis. (Option A ruled out)
  • Amino acids act as building blocks for proteins, not for steroidogenesis. (Option C ruled out)
  • Polysaccharides function as carbohydrate energy storage, unrelated to steroid hormone production. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Activation of the sympathetic nervous system

questions.text: Stress causes which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Stress (such as infection, surgery, hypoglycemia, exercise, or severe emotional trauma) activates multiple hormonal and neural pathways.
  • It causes the release of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) from the hypothalamus.
  • Stress also stimulates arginine vasopressin (AVP) secretion, which works synergistically with CRH to stimulate ACTH release.
  • Additionally, stress activates the sympathetic nervous system, increasing catecholamine output (adrenaline and noradrenaline).
  • CRH-mediated HPA axis activation leads to increased ACTH and cortisol production, ensuring the body's adaptation to stress.

questions.text: Which of the following features of Cushing's syndrome is considered more specific?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Signs & symptoms of hypercortisolism such as hypertension, obesity, or diabetes are non-specific.
  • Cushing's syndrome should be suspected when obesity is associated with features of protein catabolism.
  • Features of protein catabolism include easy bruising, proximal myopathy, facial plethora, and broad violaceous striae.
  • Osteoporosis and fractures in obese patients should further raise suspicion.
  • Hence, broad violaceous striae is more specific compared to general features like obesity and hypertension.

Explanation of other options:

Hypertension (Option A): Common but non-specific and seen in many disorders.

Moon facies (Option B): Characteristic but still non-specific for Cushing's.

Obesity (Option D): Very common finding but not unique to Cushing's.

questions.text: In a patient with Addison's disease, which of the following also occurs with increased frequency?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common cause of Addison's disease is autoimmune adrenalitis, which has multiple autoimmune associations.
  • Antibodies are most frequently directed against the 21-hydroxylase enzyme.
  • Autoimmune Addison's disease shows increased incidence of:
    • Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis → hypo/hyperthyroidism
    • Pernicious anaemia
    • Myasthenia gravis
    • Type 1 diabetes mellitus, ovarian failure, vitiligo, alopecia, and celiac disease

Explanation of Other Options:

Hypo-/Hyperthyroidism (Option A): Commonly associated due to autoimmune thyroiditis.

Pernicious anaemia (Option B): Occurs as part of autoimmune polyglandular syndrome.

Myasthenia gravis (Option C): Seen less commonly but reported in autoimmune clusters.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of primary aldosteronism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The typical triad in primary aldosteronism includes:
    1. Systemic hypertension (often resistant). (Option A)
    2. Hypokalemia (due to renal potassium loss). (Option C)
    3. Metabolic alkalosis (not acidosis).
  • Primary aldosteronism is most commonly due to bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, followed by Conn's syndrome (aldosterone-producing adenoma).
  • Patients are also at increased risk of cardiovascular mortality compared to those with essential hypertension. (Option B)

questions.text: In adrenal insufficiency, during fever, the dose of hydrocortisone should be?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During intercurrent illness such as fever, the hydrocortisone dose should be doubled to meet the increased metabolic demands.
  • In cases of severe fever or illness, the dose may even need to be tripled.
  • This approach is part of the sick day rules for adrenal insufficiency patients, designed to prevent adrenal crisis.
  • Patient education about dose adjustment during illness is crucial for preventing decompensation.

Additional Clinical Note (Acute Adrenal Insufficiency Treatment):

  • Acute adrenal insufficiency requires urgent rehydration, typically with saline infusion at an initial rate of 1 L/h under continuous cardiac monitoring.
  • Glucocorticoid replacement should start with 100 mg IV hydrocortisone bolus, followed by 200 mg hydrocortisone over 24 hours, preferably via continuous infusion or alternatively by repeated IV/IM bolus.

Explanation of other options:

Kept the same (Option A): Incorrect; failure to increase dose during stress risks adrenal crisis.

Parenteral 100 mg hydrocortisone (Option C): This is the treatment for acute adrenal crisis, not routine management of fever in stable patients.

Quadrupled (Option D): Excessive; standard recommendation is doubling or, at most, tripling in severe cases.

questions.text: A very high concentration of which of the following is diagnostic of classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A markedly elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone level (≥242 nmol/L; normal < 3 nmol/L at 3 days in a full-term infant) is diagnostic of classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • In 21-hydroxylase deficiency, the block in cortisol and aldosterone synthesis leads to shunting of precursors toward androgen production.
  • This results in low glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids with excess adrenal androgens, explaining the clinical features of virilization and salt-wasting.
  • Measurement of 17-hydroxyprogesterone is the gold standard screening and confirmatory test for CAH.

Explanation of other options:

Androstenedione (Option A): May be elevated but is not specific; it reflects general androgen excess.

11-deoxycortisol (Option B): Elevated in 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, not 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Pregnenolone (Option D): A steroid precursor but not specific or diagnostic for CAH.

choices.text: Review of CT scan to exclude hyperplasia of the left adrenal gland

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is evaluated for hyperaldosteronism because of difficult-to-control hypertension. He is otherwise healthy. Evaluation was done during treatment with agents that do not affect aldosterone or renin levels and include an aldosterone-to-renin ratio of more than 40 and a lack of aldosterone suppression to oral salt loading. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the adrenal glands shows a 1-cm mass on the right with a density of 10 HU. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Adrenal venous sampling (AVS) is the gold standard to determine the source of aldosterone excess (unilateral vs bilateral).
  • CT findings alone are insufficient, as adrenal incidentalomas may represent non-functioning tumors and cannot distinguish unilateral from bilateral disease.
  • If AVS confirms unilateral disease, the patient is a good candidate for laparoscopic adrenalectomy.
  • If AVS shows bilateral disease, medical therapy with mineralocorticoid antagonists such as eplerenone or spironolactone is the preferred management.

Explanation of Other Options:

Right laparoscopic adrenalectomy (Option B): Adrenalectomy should only be considered if AVS confirms unilateral aldosterone excess.

Treatment with eplerenone (Option C): Eplerenone is used when bilateral hyperaldosteronism is diagnosed or when surgery is contraindicated.

Review of CT scan to exclude hyperplasia of the left adrenal gland (Option D): Reviewing CT does not help differentiate unilateral from bilateral disease; functional testing is essential.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of Cushing syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common overall cause of Cushing's syndrome is the exogenous use of glucocorticoids.
  • Among the endogenous causes, the most common is an ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma (Cushing's disease).
  • Other endogenous causes include adrenal adenoma/carcinoma and ectopic ACTH secretion, but these are less frequent compared to pituitary-dependent disease.

Explanation of other options:

Adrenocortical adenoma (Option B): Can produce cortisol but is a less common cause compared to pituitary adenoma.

Adrenocortical carcinoma (Option C): Rare cause; usually associated with aggressive clinical course and poor prognosis.

Ectopic ACTH secretion (Option D): Often due to small-cell lung carcinoma or neuroendocrine tumors but occurs less frequently than pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is associated with the development of pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • MEN 2 (both 2A and 2B), not MEN 1, is associated with pheochromocytoma.
  • Von Hippel-Lindau disease is a well-recognized syndrome predisposing to pheochromocytoma.
  • Other syndromes linked with pheochromocytoma include Neurofibromatosis type 1 and Carney's triad.
  • Turner syndrome and MEN 1 are not typically associated with pheochromocytoma.

Explanation of other options:

MEN 1 (Option A): Associated with parathyroid, pancreatic, and pituitary tumors, not pheochromocytoma.

Turner syndrome (Option C): Linked to gonadal dysgenesis and cardiovascular anomalies, not pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the commonest cause of ectopic ACTH secretion leading to Cushing's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ectopic ACTH secretion is most commonly due to occult bronchial carcinoid tumors, which are often small and difficult to localize.
  • These tumors are frequently located in the lung, but ectopic ACTH can also arise from thymus or pancreas tumors.
  • Because of their small size and indolent nature, bronchial carcinoids may escape detection for long periods, contributing significantly to ectopic Cushing's syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

Thymoma (Option A): Rarely causes ectopic ACTH; more commonly associated with myasthenia gravis.

Small cell lung cancer (Option B): Can produce ectopic ACTH, but less frequent than bronchial carcinoids.

Medullary thyroid cancer (Option D): May rarely secrete ACTH, but not a common cause.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is more suggestive of an ectopic ACTH secretion rather than Cushing's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ectopic ACTH secretion is usually characterized by rapid onset of symptoms and severe biochemical abnormalities compared to pituitary Cushing's disease.
  • Hypokalemia is more prominent in ectopic ACTH secretion due to markedly increased mineralocorticoid activity of cortisol.
  • Hyperpigmentation may also occur because of extremely elevated ACTH levels stimulating melanocyte-stimulating hormone receptors.
  • In contrast, severe obesity is more typical of pituitary-dependent Cushing's disease. (Option A ruled out)

The commonest causes of aldosteronism are:

  • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia (60%)
  • Adrenal adenoma (Conn's syndrome)
  • Glucocorticoid-remediable hyperaldosteronism

Less common causes include:

  • Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME)
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Glucocorticoid resistance: Adrenocortical carcinoma
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • Progesterone-induced hypertension
  • Liddle's syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is the commonest cause of aldosteronism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The commonest cause of primary aldosteronism is bilateral adrenal hyperplasia (≈60%).
  • Adrenal adenoma (Conn's syndrome) accounts for around 30-35% of cases. (Option B ruled out)
  • Other rare causes include glucocorticoid-remediable hyperaldosteronism and syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME).
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma and Cushing's syndrome are not common causes of primary aldosteronism. (Options C and D ruled out)

The commonest causes of aldosteronism are:

  • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia (60%)
  • Adrenal adenoma (Conn's syndrome)
  • Glucocorticoid-remediable hyperaldosteronism

Less common causes include:

  • Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME)
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Glucocorticoid resistance: Adrenocortical carcinoma
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • Progesterone-induced hypertension
  • Liddle's syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive agents will not affect the aldosterone-renin ratio?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Calcium channel blockers do not significantly affect the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) and therefore do not alter the aldosterone-renin ratio.
  • Beta blockers decrease renin release, artificially lowering renin levels and potentially increasing the ARR. (Option A)
  • ACE inhibitors and ARBs increase renin activity and reduce aldosterone, thereby lowering the ARR. (Option B)
  • Diuretics increase renin secretion, which can also affect the ARR. (Option C)
  • Hence, calcium channel blockers are considered safe agents when ARR testing is performed for the diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism.
